paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Improvements in Rf Multi Cusp Negative Ion Source
paper.abstract: D-PaceÂ¿s 13.56 MHz Radio Frequency (RF) multi cusp negative ion source uses an Aluminium Nitride (AlN) dielectric window for coupling RF power from an external antenna to the plasma chamber. Ion source operation was limited to low RF power (< 3500 W) due to failures (cracks) occurring on the window during experiments. Such events can cause damages to the vacuum system and plasma chamber. The current work deals with simulations performed on the ion source to study the factors leading to the failure of the window. Based on results from the simulations, a new design was introduced. The improved design yielded positive results in terms of source performance and stability of the AlN window.

paper.title: Design Status of an Electron Source Test Lab at the Canadian Light Source
paper.abstract: An electron source test laboratory is being designed and implemented at the Canadian Light Source. Scientists at the CLS will investigate both the properties of different gun designs and the production of femtosecond pulsed, bright, low emittance beams. This lab is a means to determining the proper gun design required as a backup in the current synchrotron, and the future facility electron source. The labs location, next to the 250MeV electron linac, requires sufficient radiation shielding and integration into the existing access control and interlock system, as well as sufficient power and cooling supplies for the lab equipment. Currently, a budget is being developed for the lab by considering the requirements of various electron guns and their diagnostics.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Development of a Penning Ion Source Test Stand for Production of Alpha Particles
paper.abstract: Medical cyclotron manufacturers are seeking less-costly and more compact ion sources than Electron Cyclotron Resonance Ion Sources (ECRIS) for alpha particle production, which are currently capable of generating beam currents up to 2 mA at energies of 30 keV for axial injection into these cyclotrons. Penning Ion Sources by comparison are relatively old technologies mostly used for cheap singly-charged ion production. However, these ion sources have been used in the past for high-current multiply-charged state ion production of heavy ions up to a few mA of current, and are much smaller, cheaper, and less complex than ECRISs. Therefore, we are developing a Penning Ion source test stand to produce high-current alpha-particles for medical cyclotrons. This requires designs and simulations of all the primary components of the ion source. This system will be used to fully characterize the output beam current and internal plasma properties as a function of varying gas pressure, ion source geometries, magnetic field strength, arc voltage/current, and material properties. The result will be a source optimized for maximum alpha particle beam currents, to be used as a prototype for a commercial Penning Ion Source.
paper.footnote: * J. Bennet. A Review of PIG Sources for Multiply Charged Heavy Ions. IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science, 1972.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Advanced Beam Transport Solutions for ELIMAIA: A User Oriented Laser-Driven Ion Beamlines
paper.abstract: Laser-target acceleration represents a promising alternative to standard accelerators for several potential applications, especially medical ones, but some extreme features make laser-driven ion beams not directly usable. Therefore, a large effort has been recently devoted to development of beam-transport solutions to obtain controlled and reproducible beams. In this framework, a collaboration has been established between INFN-LNS (IT) and Eli-Beamlines-IoP (CZ) to realize a complete transport beam-line, named ELIMED, dedicated to the transport, diagnostics and dosimetry of laser-driven ion beams. The transport beamline is made by three sections: a set of high field gradient permanent magnet quadrupoles with large acceptance is used to collect and inject ions in the selection section; a magnetic chicane made of C-shaped resistive dipoles is able to select beams with high resolution and to work as an active energy modulator. The final beam shaping is done by two resistive quadrupoles. In this contribution the status of the beamline is described together with the tests performed with conventional accelerators at INFN-LNS. Feasibility study of possible upgrades are also reported.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Tests at High RF Power of the ESS Medium Beta Cryomodule Demonstrator
paper.abstract: CEA is in charge of the 30 elliptical medium and high-beta cryomodules to be installed in the ESS tunnel in Lund, Sweden. Before launching the assembly of the series cryomodules, CEA developed a medium-beta cryomodule technology demonstrator in a collaboration with IPNO, LASA and ESS. This paper briefly presents the cryomodule assembly and summarizes the main results of the high RF power tests performed in 2018 in a dedicated test stand in CEA Saclay. The main ESS requirements were reached: Eacc = 16.7 MV/m in cavities, Pforward = 1.1 MW in power couplers, RF pulses length = 3.6 ms at 14 Hz. The piezo tuners efficiently compensated the Lorentz forces detuning and could stabilize the accelerating field better than 1% over the full length of the expected ESS 2.86 ms beam pulse without any LLRF regulation system. Following this successful validation CEA started the assembly of the first ESS medium-beta series cryomodule

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: SPIRAL2 RFQ Bunch Length and Longitudinal Emittance Measurements.
paper.abstract: The SPIRAL2 RFQ is designed to accelerate light and heavy ions up to A/Q=3 in CW mode to 0.75MeV/u. During its commissioning, the bunch lengths measured using a Beam Extension Monitor were compared with simulations for different ion species (Proton, Helium, Oxygen, Argon). The longitudinal emittances measured using the 3 gradients method and a multiparticule optimization method were also compared successfully to the expected ones.

abstract_log.comments:
The paper shows interesting experimental progress and simulations on the longitudinal beam properties of the SPIRAL2 RFQ. However, the presentation can be improved and explanations are somehow scarce. Please find my comments and questions below.
- Title: lenghts --> lengths
- Since it is a paper about the RFQ beam properties, it would be good to report the main RFQ parameters (frequency, length, voltage/power, ...) or reference them.
- Please introduce acronyms when they are used the first time: e.g. ECR, RFQ, CW. Use them consistently throughout the paper, e.g. either TOF or ToF.
- Table 1: Please specify what is meant with 'ion option'.
- 'two specialized ECR ion sources'. Specialized for what? E.g. light/heavier ions?
- 'For the longitudinal plane (Figure 1)': It is not clear to me how Figure 1 shows/explains the longitudinal plane/setup.
- What is meant with 'minimum possible measurement'? The minimum time resolution?
- '150um'. Add space between number and unit.
- It seems that the two paragraphs after Figure 1 are mainly taken from the paper R. Ferdinand et al., STATUS OF SPIRAL2 AND RFQ BEAM COMMISSIONING, LINAC16, including the reference to [9], which doesn't exist in this paper.
- Fig. 2: The picture quality is relatively low. Please update with a higher quality figure.
- Table 1 (RFQ measured beam energy): There is already a Table 1 above. Please renumber. You mention Toutatis in the table, but it is not mentioned in the text. Please explain/reference.
- 'The proton beam energy was measured for beam intensity from ... to ... (Table 1)'. However, in Table 1, there is no intensity mentioned. What effect of the beam intensity on the beam energy did you expect?
- 'The slits induce a phase shift which depends on the buncher phase' I think this need more explanation.
- Fig. 3: Please mention which code was used for the simulation. The color axis has no label and no units. There are two closing brackets after mm.
- 'is not scrambled by charge force.' I assume it should be 'space-charge forces'? Please rephrase/add more explanation.
- Bunch length: The first two paragraphs, including Fig. 4 and Table 1, are already published in R. Ferdinand et al., STATUS OF SPIRAL2 AND RFQ BEAM COMMISSIONING, LINAC16, but the paper is not mentioned.
- Fig. 4: The color axis has no label and no units. The picture quality is relatively low.
- Fig. 5: lenght --> length
- Fig. 6: There is no unit for the vertical axis.
- Table 2: Do we know what error bars are expected for the measurement?
- Fig. 7: This figure is not easily visible and seems overloaded. Please consider rearranging/splitting it and add some explanation on the measurement method in the caption or text. What is meant with 'It's roughly true here' in the text box? The figure should be mentioned/referred to in the text.
- Eqs. 1,2,3: All variables used in formulas should be introduced.
- 'hypothesis'. For me these are rather assumptions that you use than a hyppothesis that you test.
- G(I). Please introduce meaning of G(I).
- Fig. 9: The picture quality is relatively low. 'Electrique' --> 'Electric'
- 'showing that first order is sufficient'. Sufficient for which purpose?
- Table 3: It might be good to add a short discussion of the results for the interesting comparisons in this table.
- Which error bars did you use for z, L, V, gamma? What is the expected error for the emittance measurement?

abstract_log.comments:
The paper presents interesting experimental progress and beam simulations on the longitudinal beam properties of the SPIRAL2 RFQ, which I consider worth to be published. However, in my opinion, the presentation of the results does not fulfill the required standards for peer-reviewed publication, starting with figures that are not reproduced in good quality with text and numbers that are not or barely readable.
Please find below some of my comments for the second version of the paper. In principal, I still believe that the issues could be fixed, but I don't see the time for further iterations during the IPAC light peer review process. Therefore, I suggest to revise the paper carefully, add further explanations and consider to submit it at a later stage for a full peer-review, for which I see the potential.
Comments: - Fig. 3: The numbers of the color axis are barely readable. The label 'Density (Relative scale)' was now added for the color axis (with presumably red = high density), but in the caption it is stated that losses are shown in red. What is the relation of high density and particles being lost on the slits? Why are there particles lost (red areas) close to the axis (i.e. inside the slits)? I believe that the paper would gain by a clear discussion/explanation of these effects.
- Caption Fig. 3: 'particule' --> 'particle'
- Fig. 4 and the text above are almost identical to R. Ferdinand et al., STATUS OF SPIRAL2 AND RFQ BEAM COMMISSIONING, LINAC16, WE1A06. As suggested, you now included the reference to the paper, however, there is no additional interpretation added. The quality of the figure is worse than in the original paper.
- Fig. 7 has still low quality. The axes labels are barely readable. The position of the beamline elements (e.g. of the rebuncher) are not visible/indicated. There is no legend for the red/blue curves in the upper plots.
- The variables used in Eq. 2 are still not introduced/explained in the text.
- Fig. 9: The legend of the rebuncher-field plot is cut/not readable.
- You state that 'The reasonable difference can be explained by the measurement errors for different parameters (z, L, V, gamma)'. Which error bars did you assume for z, L, V, gamma? What is, thus, the expected error for the emittance measurement?
abstract_log.editor_notes:
I now put Criterion 4 to 'No' because of the mentioned issues regarding - figures of insufficient quality with text and numbers not readable, missing legends, ... - not sufficient or confusing explanation added for the second version.
I see, however, no fundamental problem with the presented methods, results and conclusion (why I had originally put a 'Yes').
Please note that several paragraphs of the paper and one figure are taken from a, not peer-reviewed, LINAC16 paper by the authors (R. Ferdinand et al., STATUS OF SPIRAL2 AND RFQ BEAM COMMISSIONING, LINAC16, WE1A06).

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: The Pulsing Chopper-Based System of the Arronax C70XP Cyclotron
paper.abstract: The Arronax Public Interest Group (GIP) uses a multi-particle cyclotron to perform irradiation from a few pA up to hundreds of uA on various experiments and targets *. To support further low intensity usage and extend the beam time structure required for experiments such as pulsed experiments studies (radiolysis, proton therapeutic irradiation) and high intensity impact studies, it has been devised a pulsing system in the injection of the cyclotron. This system combines the use of a chopper, low frequency switch, and a control system based on the new extended EPICS network. This paper details the pulsing system adopted at Arronax, the last results in terms of time structure, various low intensity experimental studies performed with alpha and proton beams and the dedicated photon diagnostics.
paper.agency: This work is, in part, supported by a grant from the French National Agency for Research called "Investissements d'Avenir", Equipex Arronax-Plus noANR-11-EQPX-0004 and LabexIRON noANR-11-LABX-18-01.
paper.footnote: * F.Poirier et al., "Studies and Upgrades on the C70 Cyclotron Arronax", CYC16, September 2016, TUD02.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Operating the SNS RF H- Ion Source with a 10% Duty Factor
paper.abstract: The SNS (Spallation Neutron Source) (radio-frequency) RF-driven, H- ion source injects ~50 mA of H- beam into the SNS accelerator at 60 Hz with a 6% duty factor. It injects up to 7 AÂ·hrs of H- ions during its ~14-week service cycles, which is an unprecedented lifetime for small-emittance, high-current pulsed H- ion sources. The SNS source also features unprecedented low cesium consumption and can be installed and started up in <10 h. Presently, the LANSCE (Los Alamos Neutron Science CEnter) accelerator complex in Los Alamos is fed by a filament-driven, biased converter-type H- source that operates with a high plasma duty factor of 10%. It needs to be replaced every 4 weeks with a ~4 day startup phase. The measured negative beam current of 16-18 mA falls below the desired 21 mA acceptance of LANSCEÂ¿s accelerator especially since the beam contains several mA of electrons. LANSCE and SNS are exploring the possibility of using the SNS RF H- source at LANSCE to increase the H- beam current and the ion source lifetime while decreasing the startup time. For this purpose, the SNS H- source has been tested at a 10% duty factor by operating it at 120 Hz with 840 Âµs plasma pulses generated with ~30 kW of 2 MHz RF power, and extracting ~25 mA around-the-clock for 28 days. This, and additional tests and other considerations are discussed in this paper.
paper.agency: This work was performed at Oak Ridge National Laboratory under contract DE-AC05-00OR22725 and at Los Alamos National Laboratory under contract DE-AC52-06NA25396 for the U.S. Department of Energy.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Vacuum Lifetime and Surface Charge Limit Investigations Concerning High Intensity Spin-polarized Photoinjectors
paper.abstract: The Small Thermalized Electron Source at Mainz (STEAM) is a dc photoemission source. It is designed to operate at up to 200kV bias voltage with an accelerating field of up to 5 MV/m at the cathode surface. In several experiments, the properties of GaAs operating under the conditions of spin-polarized photoemission were investigated. Its performance, quantum efficiency lifetime and surface charge limit observations for bulk-GaAs will be discussed.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Emittance Reduction of RF Photoinjector Generated Electron Beams By Transverse Laser Beam Shaping
paper.abstract: Laser pulse shaping is one of the key elements to generate low emittance electron beams with RF photoinjectors. Ultimately high performance can be achieved with ellipsoidal laser pulses, but 3-dimensional shaping is challenging. High beam quality can also be reached by simple transverse pulse shaping, which has demonstrated improved beam emittance compared to a transversely uniform laser in the `pancakeÂ¿ photoemission regime. In this contribution we present the truncation of a Gaussian laser at a radius of approximately one sigma in the intermediate (electron bunch length directly after emission about the same as radius) photoemission regime with high acceleration gradients (up to 60 MV/m). This type of electron bunch is used e.g. at the European XFEL and FLASH free electron lasers at DESY, Hamburg site and is being investigated in detail at the Photoinjector Test facility at DESY in Zeuthen (PITZ). Here we present ray-tracing simulations and experimental data of a laser beamline upgrade enabling variable transverse truncation. Initial projected emittance measurements taken with help of this setup are shown, as well as supporting beam dynamics simulations. Additional simulations show the potential for substantial reduction of slice emittance at PITZ.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Characterization of an Electron Gun Test Setup Based on Multipacting
paper.abstract: A multipacting electron gun (MEG) is a micro-pulse electron source, based on secondary electron emission in a resonant microwave cavity structure, for the generation of low emittance electron bunches in continuous wave operation. Based on numerical simulations, an experimental test setup for low-energy electron beams at 3 GHz has been established. In this contribution we show a detailed description and characterization of the RF test stand, supported by first results on charge collection measurements of the output current with respect to important operational parameters like power transmission and modifiable mechanical dimensions in the assembly of the experiment. This is a milestone in the development of a MEG setup for higher energetic electron beams and subsequent investigation of essential beam characteristics like emittance and energy distribution for the optimization with regard to best possible beam quality and future fields of application.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: SINGLE SHOT CATHODE TRANSVERSE MOMENTUM IMAGING IN PHOTOINJECTORS
paper.abstract: In state of the art photoinjector electron sources, cathode performance determines the lower limit of achievable beam emittance. Measuring the thermal emittance at the photocathodes in electron guns is of vital importance for improving the injectors. Traditional methods, like solenoid scan, pepper-pot, need multi-shots and are time-consuming, therefore suffer from machine stability. Here we propose a new method, named cathode transverse momentum imaging. By tuning the gun solenoid focusing, the electrons' transverse momentum at the cathode is imaged to a downstream screen, which enables a single shot measurement. Several experiments have been done at the Photo Injector Test Facility at DESY in Zeuthen (PITZ) with a Cs2Te cathode. Measurements of cathode transverse momentum, the corresponding spectra, cathode transverse momentum map and its correlation with surface electric field are presented.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Design Steps Towards an Electron Source for Ultrafast Electron Diffraction at DELTA
paper.abstract: Ultrafast electron diffraction (UED) is a pump-probe technique to explore the structural dynamics of matter, combining sub-angstrom De-Broglie wavelength of electrons with femtosecond time resolution. UED experiments require ultrashort laser pulses to pump a sample, electron bunches with small emittance and ultrashort length to analyze the state of the sample and excellent control of the delay between them. Electrons accelerated to a few MeV in a photocathode gun offer significant advantages compared to keV electrons from electrostatic electron sources regarding emittance, bunch length and, due to the reduction of space charge effects, bunch charge. Furthermore, thicker samples and hence a wider range of possible materials are enabled by the longer mean free path of MeV electrons. In this paper, design steps towards a university-based UED facility with ultrashort and low-emittance MeV electron bunches are presented, including the transverse and longitudinal focusing schemes, which minimize space charge effects and nonlinearities.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable, Poster Police Failed
paper.title: Novel GaN Based Photocathodes Featuring a High Quantum Efficiency
paper.abstract: Prospective light sources such as the free-electron laser (FEL), as well as synchrotron- and THz radiation sources, require injectors featuring high brightness electron beams. Operating such electron injectors requires photocathodes providing features such as high quantum efficiency (QE), long lifetime, low thermal emittance, and low dark current. Unfortunately, til date, no material for photocathodes was identified satisfying all of the above mentioned requirements. The base material of the work proposed here will be gallium nitride (GaN), as GaN based photocathodes feature potential QE values of up to 50%. The thin films are synthesised on silicon- and metal substrates (e.g.: copper and niobium) by means of radio frequency magnetron sputtering in a Nitrogen (N) and/or Argon (Ar) plasma discharge. Due to the p-type doping with magnesium (Mg), the diffusion length of the excited electrons within the bulk material (GaN) and consequently the QE will be further increased. Beside standard materials science characterization techniques such as SEM, EDX, XRD or XPS, the QE will be determined in situ directly following the synthesis of the thin films. To enable the emission of exited electrons, a negative electron affinity is realized by evaporated cesium monolayers on the thin film surface. Afterwards, the material properties will be adjusted by the parameters during the synthesis with respect to the optimization of the QE.
paper.agency: This work was supported by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) under grant 05K16PS1 'HOPE II: Hochbrillante photoinduzierte Hochfrequenz-Elektronenquellen'.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable, Poster Police Failed
paper.title: Topographical Modification of Novel GaN Based Photocathodes to Increase Their Quantum Efficiency
paper.abstract: Prospective light sources such as the free-electron laser (FEL), as well as synchrotron- and THz radiation sources, require injectors featuring high brightness electron beams. Operating such electron injectors requires photocathodes providing features such as high quantum efficiency (QE), long lifetime, low thermal emittance, and low dark current. One promising candidate meeting the aforementioned specifications is gallium nitride (GaN). Therefore, thin GaN films have been synthesized on silicon- and metal substrates (e.g.: copper and niobium) by means of radio frequency magnetron sputtering (RFMS). To further increase the QE by topographical modifications of the film surface, the roughness and morphology are varied via parameter variation during RFMS and chemical wet etching with potassium hydroxide. The roughness and morphology of the surface have been evaluated by AFM and SEM, whereas the QE is measured in situ after the synthesis and ex-situ in case of the wet chemical etching treatment. The required surface activation to achieve a negative electron affinity, which enables the emission of excited electrons, is realized by means of a Cs-dispenser. Alongside the QE, in particular the thermal emittance is strongly dependent on the surface topography. Consequently, the measured thermal emittance is correlated with the QE to adjust and optimize the topography of the film surface with respect to both effects.
paper.agency: This work was supported by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF) under grant 05K16PS1 'HOPE II: Hochbrillante photoinduzierte Hochfrequenz-Elektronenquellen'.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable
paper.title: THz-Based Relativistic Electron Bunch Acceleration in Vacuum
paper.abstract: The advantage of using THz pulses for particle acceleration is that their wavelengths are longer by two orders of magnitude than that of the pulses in the visible or in the near-infrared range. Thus, the interaction length with the particles can be extended and a good synchronism between the pulse and the particles is possible.* We proposed Compact THz-based Electron Acceleration (C-TEA) setup driven by 0.5 mJ THz energy per pulse. We numerically investigated the acceleration and the manipulation of electron bunches by four-four in couples counter-propagating focused THz pulses with 0.3 and 0.14 THz mean frequency, respectively. The setup consists of 4 main parts and the size of the whole system is 71 mm. The electrons that generated in a gas jet can be accelerated from rest up to 80 keV in the 1st acceleration stage and they are post-accelerated to 350 keV in the 2nd acceleration stage. The extended transversal and longitudinal bunch size caused by space charge was reduced as much as possible using solenoids and bunch compression technique. Using altogether around 4 mJ THz energy the C-TEA can produce electron bunches with 150 fs duration, 2.5 % energy spread and higher than 350 keV energy.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable
paper.title: Ultra-Short Relativistic Electron Bunch Acceleration by THz-Based Waveguide Structure
paper.abstract: THz sources and THz-driven compact acceleration schemes have been developed continuously over the past decade. Here we propose a new waveguide-structure based electron acceleration setup using THz pulses with 0.3 THz mean frequency. The acceleration and the manipulation of electron bunches are investigated numerically. The size of the whole setup is 50 mm and consists of 3 parts. At the first part the generated electrons with charge of 1 fC from a gold surface are accelerated from rest up to 46 keV by two horn-shaped waveguide-structures in a row. Using only 30 ÂµJ THz pulse energy we can achieve higher than 6.5 MV/cm peak electric field inside the structure, hence high acceleration gradient can be achieved. At the second part we used phase-space manipulation in vacuum by two pairs of THz pulses with 0.4 ÂµJ energy per pulse to compress the bunch longitudinally, while the increased transversal size of bunch is reduced by a solenoid magnet. Using around 60 ÂµJ all energy, our setup provides ultra-narrow energy spread (~0.22 %) and ultrashort (~100 fs) electron bunch.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Basic Design of the RF Power System for IRANCYC-10 Accelerator
paper.abstract: In this paper the basic design of an RF system to produce the required power of IRANCYC-10 cyclotron accelerator is reported. The designed system can generate 15 kW power at the operating frequency of 71 MHz CW. The authors provide a step-by-step ex-planation of the process of the design. It is carried out in three sections; (1) RF design features of the acceler-ator is investigated and power value is calculated in accordance with the requirements of the cyclotron, (2) the choice of solid state amplifiers as the RF power source is presented with its available power and struc-ture, (3) design of insertion instruments is reported to transfer and combine the RF power. The purpose of the paper is to achieve the best performance of the RF system, as well as decreasing overall size by using modular devices.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: A CENTRAL REGION UPGRADE OF THE k800 SUPERCONDUCTING CYCLOTRON AT INFN-LNS
paper.abstract: The Superconducting Cyclotron (CS) at INFN-LNS in Catania is currently under an upgrade process. The plan is to deliver beams of ions with mass number 𝐴 ≤ 40 with power up to 10 kW. This ambitious goal can be achieved increasing the efficiency of the injection and extraction processes. An extraction efficiency close to 100% is expected by extracting the specific ion beams from the CS by stripping and no longer by electrostatic deflectors. The beams are injected axially and bent onto the median plane with a spiral inflector. Currently, the injection efficiency stays around 15%, also including the effect of a drift buncher placed in the axial injection line. In order to increase the injection efficiency, the study of an upgraded CS central region is ongoing at INFN-LNS. In this paper, the results of simulations of beam tracking through the cyclotron axial bore, the spiral inflector, the central region and further up to the extraction system are presented.

abstract_log.comments:
The paper deals with the upgrade of a superconducting cyclotron to be able to deliver 100 times the current beam power for the nuclear physics program and other applications at the INFN-LNS Catania. The upgrade involves the redesign of the beam injection and extraction as well as the central region of the cyclotron. The paper is sound but I have the following questions, comments and corrections:
1. The proposed beam power upgrade from 100 W to 10 kW is significant, is it all coming from the beam intensity upgrade? Or the beam energies will also be higher?
2. What is the current extraction efficiency of the beam? You mentioned that itÂ¿ll be close to 100% by replacing the extraction deflector by stripping, but how much will that improve the intensity?
3. The current injection efficiency is 15% and could be improved by a factor of 3-4 based on table 2 results. Where will the remaining factor of 25 in beam power come from? Could it all be coming from the new extraction system?
4. In the text, it was mentioned that the maximum beam power does not exceed 100 W due to beam loss on the first of the two electrostatic deflectors. Does your current extraction have two deflectors?
5. The stripping extraction will also increase the energy spread of the beam, have you estimated this effect for a typical beam.
6. Figure 2 is too small to see or read.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Design of a Full C-Band Injector for Ultra-High Brightness Electron Beam
paper.abstract: High gradient rf photo-injectors have been a key development to enable several applications of high quality electron beams. They allow the generation of beams with very high peak current and low transverse emittance, satisfying the tight demands for free-electron lasers, energy recovery linacs, Compton/Thomson sources and high-energy linear colliders. In the paper we present the design of a new full C-band RF photo-injector recently developed in the framework of the XLS-Compact Light design study and of the EuPRAXIA@SPARC_LAB proposal. It allows to reach extremely good beam performances in terms of beam emittance (at the level of few hundreds nm), energy spread and peak current. The photo-injector is based on a very high gradient (>200 MV/m) ultra-fast (RF pulses <200 ns) C-band RF gun, followed by two C band TW structures. Different types of couplers for the 1.6 cell RF gun have been considered and also a new compact low pulsed heating coupler working on the TM020 mode on the full cell has been proposed. In the paper we report the design criteria of the gun, the powering system, and the results of the beam dynamics simulations. We also discuss the case of 1 kHz repetition rate.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Arc and Convertor Current Transient Studies for Multi-cusp Cesiated Surface Conversion H- Source at Lansce
paper.abstract: The Multi-cusp Cesiated Surface Conversion H- Ion Source at the Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE) has provided beam at ~14 mA, 120 Hz, and 10% D.F. for many years of neutron science research. Recently, random high current transients were discovered in the arc current used to ionize hydrogen in the LANSCE H- ion source, and in the convertor current used to convert protons to H- ions. Most have no effect, but more severe transients can cripple beam output. Hypothesized causes are related to cesiation effects, plasma potential changes, tungsten filament vaporation/sputtering, or from the pulsed power system. A dedicated study was recently done on the LANSCE H- Ion source test stand to determine the cause of these transients. Current understanding indicates that the more severe transients come from a combination of cesiation effects and plasma potential changes. The status of these current transient studies on the LANSCE H- ion source will be discussed.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Negative Electron Affinity GaAs Cathode Activation With CsKTe Thin Film
paper.abstract: Negative Electron Affinity (NEA) GaAs cathode is an unique device which can generate a highly polarized electron beam with circularly polarized light. The NEA surface is conventionally made by Cs and $\rm O/NF_3$ adsorption on the cleaned p-doped GaAs crystal, but the robustness of the cathode is very limited, so that the electron emission is easily lost by residual gas adsorption, ion back-bombardment, etc. To improve the cathode robustness, NEA activation with a stable thin-film on GaAs surface according to Hetero junction hypothesis has been proposed by the author. An experiment of the NEA activation with CsKTe thin film was carried out at Hiroshima University and a significant electron emission with 1.43 eV photon was observed which strongly suggested NEA activation. The cathode showed 16 to 20 times improvement of lifetime comparing to GaAs activated with Cs and O.

abstract_log.comments: This is a well-written article with a significant breakthrough in polarized beam source. In future study, it would be interesting to see how this novel method using CsKTe performs in terms of polarization, which was not reported here. Other minor comment is about error bar, which is absent in Fig.4. That would have helped the readers to convince themselves about the lifetime estimation appearing in Table1 (1st entry)-Is it fitting error (RMS deviation), or measurement error? Also, I could not find the intensity of photo-electrons (only the ratio QE). So I am curious if the NEA with CsKTe continues to perform as robust as this report when a more realistic (~mA or even higehr) beam current is required.
abstract_log.editor_notes: This is a well-written article with a significant breakthrough in a polarized beam source. The follow-up study in higher intensity regime could lead to a realistic polarized beam source with much more robust performance than current methods.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Progress of J-PARC LINAC Commissioning
paper.abstract: After energy and intensity upgrade to 400MeV and 50mA respectively, J-PARC linac were ready for 1 MW beam power from RCS. J-PARC is now successfully operated at 50mA/400MeV for 500kW at neutron target, and on the way to 1MW. The next milestones 1.2 and 1.5MW from RCS are relying on feasibility and property of increase of peak current to 60 mA and the pulse width to 600us in linac. Beam studies were carried out at linac to study the initial beam parameters from ion source/RFQ, to find the optimized lattice and matching, to clarify beam loss source and to mitigate the loss/residue dose for the power upgrade.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Extraction System of Upgraded AVF Cyclotron of RCNP
paper.abstract: The AVF cyclotron of RCNP have been utilized for the purposes of basic research in physics, RI production for medicine and industrial applications as well as injector of ring cyclotron. Increasing beam intensity without decreasing beam quality can make improvements in all purposes. The improvement and repair of the AVF cyclotron are being carried out currently. We designed the new LEBT, injection, acceleration and extraction systems and we report on the extraction system here. High extraction efficiency is indispensable when increasing the beam intensity since beam loss causes activation of apparatus. New extraction system consists of deflector electrodes and two gradient correctors and probes. One gradient corrector causes a horizontally focus effect on the beam and the other causes horizontally defocus effect to avoid spreading of the beam with strong defocus effect caused by the main cyclotron magnetic field. Simulation study confirmed that 10 MeV proton, 65 MeV proton and 140 MeV alpha particles with 2 mm Ã 3 mrad could pass through the newly designed extraction system and the existing beam transport line. Beam simulation has been performed by utilizing SNOP* and OPAL** codes.
paper.footnote: * SNOP V.L. Smirnov, S.B. Vorozhtsov, Proc. of RUPAC2012 TUPPB008 325 (2012) ** The OPAL (Object Oriented Parallel Accelerator Library) Framework, Andreas Adelmann et al., PSI-PR-08-02, (2008-2018)

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: The New Eddy Current type Septum Magnets for Upgrading of Fast Extraction in Main Ring of J-PARC
paper.abstract: The J-PARC Main Ring (MR) is working on imporved beam to 750 kW by shorting the repetition period from 2.48 s to 1.3 s which we call 1Hz operation. The septum magnets for fast extraction in MR will be improved to the new septum magnets which can operate 1Hz. The new magnets will be installed to MR in 2021. In this poster we will report about the new low field septum magnet for the fast extraction. The present septum magnets are conventional type. Therefore, we have problem in durability of thin septum coil by its magnetic vibration, and large leakage field at the exit of the circulating beam duct. The new septum magnets are eddy current type. The eddy current type does not have septum coil, but has a thin septum plate. We can expect that there is no problem in durability of septum coil, and leakage field can be reduced. The output of the present power supply are pattern current which of flat top is 10 ms width, the new one is short pulse which of one is 10 us. The short pulse consists of fundamental and 3rd harmonic sin-wave pulse. We can expect that the flatness and reproducibility of flat top current can be improved. We confirmed that 1Hz operation and high accuracy of its output current and magnetic field with the new septum magnet system. We had some problem in unexpected instability of output current. In this report we also summarize the measure against the instabillity.

abstract_log.comments:
Dear Authors, thank you for preparing this paper.
It offers a good summary showing a solid engineering work towards the improved fast extraction septa of the J-PARC Main Ring, with a methodical scrutiny of the successful results (1 Hz operation) and of the pending issues (magnetic leakage, switching time latency between Main-charger and Sub-charger, jittery in the trigger signal, incompatibility between the current transformers reading). The contents are supported with clear and accurately labeled illustrations.
On the other hand, the presentation style and the English phrasing have margins for being improved. In order to match the quality of the scientific contents, I suggest consolidating the paper form.
In the following I give some proposals and examples. I would rephrase the first sentence as Â¿The J-PARC Main Ring (MR) team is currently working on upgrading the machine power reach to 750 kW by increasing the beam repetition rate from 0.4 to 0.78 Hz. This new operation mode is referred as "1 Hz" operationÂ¿. More in general I suggest to use impersonal or passive verbs, to pay attention to the subject of the sentence (the team) and to split a long sentence in shorter ones.
In the paper there are several typos or inconsistencies with the adopted symbols, e.g.: T .Shibata -> T. Shibata which is conventional type -> which are conventional ones P.S. -> PS Edd -> Eddy the total capacitance 875 us -> check the units Tesla -> T maximum repetition rate -> maximum repetition period ( average ) -> (average) Thus, more modification will be needed to reduce the switching time. -> I suggest being more informative. by using the difference monitor systems -> by using the different monitor systems which is feedback system -> which is a feedback system Â¿ M.Kinsho-> M. Kinsho
I suggest also to rename the section Â¿The issues we must solveÂ¿ in Â¿Pending technical issuesÂ¿. For the `ReferencesÂ¿ section, please consider adding a general paper of the eddy current septa principle.
abstract_log.editor_notes: The paper gives the status of the engineering work for the upgrade of the fast extraction septa of J-PARC Main Ring. Concerning the contents, I consider that it meets the standard for the IOP Conference proceedings series but, as far as the quality of the English form, I urged the Authors to improve it.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: The New High Field Septum Magnets for Upgrading of Fast Extraction in Main Ring of J-PARC
paper.abstract: The J-PARC Main Ring (MR) is working on imporved beam to 750 kW by shorting the repetition period from 2.48 s to 1.3 s which we call 1Hz operation. There are fout high field septum magnet along the fast extraction line in the MR, and these will be improved to the new magnets which can operate 1Hz frequency. The new high field septa will be installed in 2021. In this poster we will report about the performance of these new septum magnets. These high field septum magnets are called Septum 30(SM30),31(SM31), 32(SM32), 33(SM33). We will replace SM30, SM31, and SM32. One reasons of cethe replacement is installation of a large-size quadrupole magnet to upsteam postion of the septa. We need to change the longitudinal length of the septa. Second is large aperture of the beam duct for reduction of beam loss by the collision of the halo of the proton beam to the duct. The new high field SM30, SM31 and SM32 have large aperture. and the material of the beam ducts for extraction line are ceramics for reduction of amount of heat generation by eddy current on the surface of the duct. The maetial of the circulating duct are titanium for reduction of radioactivation. On the other hand, the power supply will not be replaced, then the current power supplies will be used for these new septa. The new SM30, SM31, and SM32 were produced in 2015. The first test operation of SM31 were conduced with 2.48 s repein 2015, and we have meaured the magnetic field without problem. In 2018, we conduced the first 1Hz operation with SM30. The minimum repetition period of the operation was 1.16 s without any problem. We measuered magnetic fields in the gap of the pole and in the circulating beam duct. In this report we will report the detail of the results of the operation and field measurement.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable
paper.title: Alumina Capillary Compact Microwave Ion Source
paper.abstract: We have been developing a novel fragmentation technique to determine unknown primary biomolecular structures by mass analyzing the cracking pattern of the target molecule through fragmentation induced by atom injection. Our LICP (Locally Inductively Coupled Plasma) source employs completely electrodeless configuration under vacuum condition to prevent contaminant emission from the parts to exposed to the plasma. A 2.45 GHz microwave power induces the microwave to a 0.3 mm thick copper spiral antenna wound around a quarter inch alumina tube through which the supply gas is injected. The input power up to 50 W excites a plasma in the tube stably. Toroidal permanent magnets arranged outside of the antenna assist ignition and sustain LICP with electron cyclotron resonance. An optical emission spectrum of hydrogen LICP shows a high atomic fraction with the intensity two orders of magnitude higher than those of excited molecules in the Fulcher band. The high degree of dissociation plasma source should have a potential application to a proton beam source. In this paper, selected ion species ratio by magnetic mass analyzer extracted from a high atomic ratio plasma source are discussed.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Radiation Design of New 30 kW Beam Dump of J-PARC Main Ring
paper.abstract: The J-PARC Main Ring (MR) has a beam dump for the beam study and beam abort. Its present capacity is 7.5 kW in one hour average which is limited by radiation condition for the environments. The number of protons in one MR cycle is 2.6e+14 in recent days, which corresponds to the beam power of 500 kW. As the top energy of J-PARC MR is 30 GeV, the number of available beam shots is restricted to less than twenty in one hour with such an intense beam. It imposes a big limitation on high power beam tuning and study. The number of protons is expected to become 3.3e+14 for MW operation. Hence, an upgrade of the beam dump from 7.5 kW to 30 kW is planned. The radiation dose rate should be less than 0.25 micro Sv/h on the ground. The backscattered neutron flux should be examined in the accelerator tunnel. The new dump design on radiation matters is described in this paper.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: J-PARC RCS: High-Order Field Components Inherent in the Injection Bump Magnets and Their Effects on the Circulating Beam During Multi-Turn Injection
paper.abstract: The J-PARC RCS utilizes four sets of pulsed dipole magnets for the formation of injection orbit bump. The injection bump magnets have a large aspect ratio (gap length/core length), so there are other high-order field components inherent in their magnetic fields in addition to the main dipole component. The high-order field components, which locally exist in the injection section not following the lattice super-periodicity, have a significant influence on the circulating beam during multi-turn injection via the excitation of high-order random betatron resonances. This paper discusses the detailed mechanism of emittance growth and beam loss caused by the high-order field components of the injection bump magnets including its correction scenario on the basis of numerical simulation and experimental results.

This work is important for high power proton synchrotron and similar machine. One minor problem: the abstract is NOT clear on conclusion of this paper. I suggest authors improve it.

institute.full_name: National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center

paper.main_class: MC7: Accelerator Technology
paper.title: Development of Low Inductance Circuit for Radially Symmetric Circuit
paper.abstract: Radiation symmetric type circuits using semiconductors of SIC-MOSFETs, one of next generation semiconductors, are composed of circuits in which many semiconductor switches are multiplexed in series and in parallel. Since the lengths of all parallel circuits are equal, the output waveform will not be distorted due to timing jitter or level change. This circuit is useful for outputting the waveform of ultrafast short pulse. Therefore, we have developed a circuit that achieves further low inductance by making the power transmission circuit into a double circular ring structure equal to the coaxial shape. Compare the inductance value obtained from the structure and the output waveform. In addition, we compare the calculation and the actual measurement in the actual test and present the verification result of the developed circular ring structure.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Vacuum Tube Operation Analysis for 1.2 MW Beam Acceleration in J-PARC RCS
paper.abstract: The J-PARC RCS has successfully accelerated 1 MW proton beam, matching the designed beam power. Therefore, we have considered acceleration beyond the designed beam power, with the next target being 1.2 MW. An issue for 1.2 MW beam acceleration is the rf system. The present anode power supply is limited by its output current, and the vacuum tube amplifier suffers from an unbalance of the anode voltage swing, arising from the combination of multi-harmonic rf driving and push-pull operation. We have investigated the mitigation of the maximum anode currents and unbalanced tubes by choosing appropriate circuit parameters of the rf cavity with the tube amplifier. We describe the analysis results of the vacuum tube operation for 1.2 MW beam acceleration in the RCS.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Operation Status of J-PARC Rapid Cycling Synchrotron
paper.abstract: The 3 GeV rapid cycling synchrotron (RCS) at the Japan Proton Accelerator Research Complex (J-PARC) provides more than 500 kW beams to the Material and Life Science Facility (MLF) and Main Ring (MR). In such a high-intensity hadron accelerator, even losing less than 0.1% of the beam can cause many problems. Such lost protons can cause serious radio-activation and accelerator component malfunctions. Therefore, we have conducted a beam study to achieve high-power operation. In addition, we have also maintained the accelerator components to enable stable operation. This paper reports the status of the J-PARC RCS over the last year.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Compact ECR Ion Source for Electrostatic Storage Ring at KACST
paper.abstract: A very compact and low cost microwave ECR ion source is being constructed for the Ion injector line in the multi- purpose low-energy, ELASR storage ring facility at the King Abdulaziz City for Science and Technology (KACST) in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The compact ECR ion source is driven with a transmitter technology similar to those used for cellular phones, and it can deliver single-charge ions with en- ergy up to 50keV and beam current up to 50μA amps. By the reduction of the size and the required microwave power and making the source operating without high-voltage platform, the overall cost of the system is significantly minimized. In this contribution, the design, modeling and simulation of the new ECR cavity and the extraction system will be introduced and discussed.

paper.title: The Operation Status of CSNS Front End
paper.abstract: China spallation neutron source (CSNS), as the China's first 100kW beam power pulsed neutron source,its operation target beam power is now larger than 50kW.During the beam power upgrading process of CSNS to 50kW from 2018 to 2019,many improvements have been made for the front end of CSNS. The improvements mainly focus on solving the stability of ion source and the spark of Radio Frequncy quadrupole (RFQ) caused by the pre-chopped beam into RFQ.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable, Poster Police Failed
paper.title: Experiments of Double-Frequency and Three-Frequency Heating in SECRAL II
paper.abstract: SECRAL II is a third generation fully superconducting ECRIS (electron cyclotron resonance ion source) and nearly a duplicated one of SECRAL. When the microwave frequency is equal to the Lamo frequency of the electron in the magnetic field, the electron resonance will absorb energy greatly from the microwave, and then collide with the neutral atom to ionize it to produce the plasma. Due to its high working frequency and multi frequency heating, many good results had been obtained as 6000euA O6+, 610euA Ar16+, 14.5euA Ar18+, 7euA Kr31+, 870euA Xe27+ and 1.3euA Xe45+. In order to explore the effect of magnetic field on high-charge ions under multi-frequency heating, experiments were carried out under microwave waves of 18+28GHz, 28+45GHz and 18+28+45GHz.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable, Poster Police Failed
paper.title: Experimental Demonstration of Laser Accelerator with Accurate Beam Control
paper.abstract: A Compact LAser Plasma Accelerator (CLAPA) that can stably produce and transport protons with different energies less than 10 MeV, less than 1% energy spread and several to tens of pC charge is demonstrated. The high current proton beam with continuous energy spectrum and a large divergence angle was generated by using a high contrast laser interacting with micron thickness targets, which later was collected, analyzed and refocused by an electromagnetic lattice using combination of quadrupole and bending electromagnets. The experiment combines the laser acceleration with a fully functional beam line, realizing the precise manipulation of the proton beams with reliability, availability, maintainability and inspectability (RAMI). For the first time, the laser driven proton beams can be precisely controlled in terms of the energy, energy spread, charge diameter and uniformity. Moreover, a radially symmetric mono-energetic pencil beams with adjustable sizes can be obtained. Spread-out Bragg peak (SOBP), the key technology of proton radiotherapy for malignant tumors, is then realized with laser accelerator for the first time. With the uniform mono-energetic pencil beams demonstrated at CLAPA, primary biomedical cell irradiation experiments and material irradiation experiments to emulate the space conditions are also carried out.
paper.agency: The National Basic Research Program of China, NSFC (GrantNos.11535001) , ITER-CHINA Program (No. 2015GB120001) and National Grand Instrument Project(2012YQ030142).

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable, Poster Police Failed
paper.title: Indutive Oven Development for Intense Metallic Ion Beam Production at IMP
paper.abstract: As the main injector of heavy ion accelerator, ECR ion sources need to provide more and more intense highly charged refractory metallic ion beams at the Institute of Modern Physics. The traditional oven used at IMP is not able to reach the temperature needed for the requested metal ion beams. In order to meet these requirements, an inductive oven with ~200 kHz of heating frequency has been proposed and fabricated. Off-line test result has shown that this oven can reach up to about 1800 ℃ at 0.5 kW of AC power. Subsequently, 58Ni was loaded into the oven and it was installed in the 28 GHz superconducting ECR ion source SECRAL-II. As a result, 360 euA of Ni17+ has been extracted successfully with ~2.5 kW of RF power and 20 kV extraction high voltage. In this contribution, we will discuss the structure of this inductive oven and analyse the testing results as well.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Simulation Analysis of LLRF Feedforward Compensation to Beam Loading for CiADS LINAC
paper.abstract: A simulation is coded to calculate the beam loading in the cavity of CiADS and the response of the LLRF system. In the pulse operating mode, the fluctuation of amplitude and phase of the cavity field contributed by the transient beam loading is traced. During the simulation the effect of beam current fluctuation, and timing jitter were determined. The deviation margin of relational parameters is lined out to meet the requirement for cavity stability with amplitude 0.1% and phase 0.1Â°.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Commissioning of a Compact THz Source Based on FEL
paper.abstract: The layout of the THz source based on FEL was de-scribed in this paper. The THz source was based on a FEL which was composed of a compact 8-14MeV LINAC, undulator, optical resonance, THz wave measurement system and so on. The facility was designed in 2013 and the typical running parameter got in 2017 were as the following: energy is of 12.7MeV, energy spread is of 0.3%, macro-pulse is of 4 μs, pulse length of micro-pulse is of 6ps, emittance is of 24 mm.mrad. After that the ma-chine was commissioning for production THz radiation. In November 2018, the THz wave was test and got THz wave signal, the spectrum was also got. This year, we plan to measure the output power of the THz source.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Improvement of 6D Brightness by a 1.4-cell Photocathode RF Gun for MeV Ultrafast Electron Diffraction
paper.abstract: Recent research indicates that ultrafast electron diffraction and microscopy (UED/M) have unprecedented potential in probing ultrafast dynamic processes, especially in organic and biological materials. However, reaching the required brightness while maintaining high spatiotemporal resolution requires new design of electron source. In order to produce ultrashort electron beam with extreme high brightness, a 1.4-cell RF gun is being developed to reach higher acceleration gradient near the photocathode and thus suppress the space charge effect in the low energy region. Simulation of the 1.4-cell RF photocathode gun shows considerable improvement in bunch length, emittance and energy spread, which all lead to better temporal and spatial resolution comparing to traditional 1.6-cell RF photocathode gun. The results demonstrate the feasibility of sub-ps temporal resolution with normalized emittance less than 0.1 πmmÂ·mrad while maintaining 1 pC electron pulse.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Preliminary Study on the Injection System Upgrade for CSNS-II
paper.abstract: The first phase of the China Spallation Neutron Source (CSNS-I) had completed the national acceptance in August, 2018. The physics design of the second phase (CSNS-II) has already begun. The CSNS-II accelerator upgrade contains three main components, including the Linac energy upgrade from 80 MeV to 300 MeV, injection system upgrade, and new Magnetic Alloy dual-harmonic cavity. In this paper, a preliminary study on the injection system upgrade had been done. A preliminary upgrade scheme for the injection system would be given. Furthermore, some preliminary simulation and calculation for the upgrade injection system had been carried out. The analysis results showed that most injection parameters can preliminarily meet the requirements of accelerator power upgrade.
paper.agency: Work supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (Project No. U1832210)

paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable
paper.title: Gun Cavity optimization and multiphysics analyzation
paper.abstract: SHINE (Shanghai HIgh repetition rate XFEL aNd Extreme light facility) Project will be a fully-coherent, high-brightness, ultra-short pulse, high gain and high repetition rate hard XFEL facility. The quality of XFEL beam is determined by performance of electron gun. In this paper, we scan the geometrical parameters of the reentrant cavity which is actually the gun itself to ascertain the incidence which the optimization is based on of each geometrical parameter to gun RF parameter, and finally obtained the approximate design with consideration of beam physics and multiphysics including temperature and multipacting.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Design and Analysis of the Cold Cathode Ion Source for 200 MeV Superconducting Cyclotron
paper.abstract: SC200 is a superconducting isochronous cyclotron which generates 200 MeV, 400 nA proton beam for particle therapy. The cold-cathode-type Penning ion gauge (PIG) ion source for the internal ion source of SC200 has been selected as an alternative and preliminary designed. In this paper, design of ion source and test bench are demonstrated. Currently, the properties of ion source have been simulated for a variety of electric field distributions and magnetic field strengths. The secondary electron emission in electromagnetic field has been simulated. It provides reference for the optimization design of arc chamber. In addition, the sample of cold-cathode-type ion source has been tested on the test bench and extracted beam intensity has been measured over 200 μA.

abstract_log.comments:
The conclusion is not clear enough. The presented results seems not be able to provide a stable working source. The required voltage to provide a beam intensity is 1500V, while it causes a discharge which stops the operation. The stability of the source should be addressed.
The work of others in the field should be acknowledged and the references should be included correctly.
abstract_log.editor_notes: This work shows a progress in construction of a cold ion source for a cyclotron. If the conclusion can clearly indicate the stability of the source it deserves a publication with a light peer review.

abstract_log.comments: 1: Typos or formatting error: MEV -> MeV; designed -> design; pressure -> voltage; twice as large as -> half of 2: I would recommend that adding the requirements for PIG ion source to SC 200 in the section of introduction. 3: Why has the hot cathode ion source been chosen for the project of SC 200? So whatÂ¿s the role of the cold cathode ion source? WhatÂ¿s the lifetime of the hot cathode ion source used in SC 200? Please specify advantages and disadvantages of these two ion sources. 4: In Busold, SimonÂ¿s work, "Recent Ion Source Developments for VARIAN's ProBeamÂ® Cyclotron.", boride crystals (LaB6 and CeB6) were used for the hot cathode materials, is there any difference between your design and his work? Please explain in more details. 5: You mentioned that there were two discharge modes, and the discharge canÂ¿t last after the second mode. Can we conclude that the ion source will stop discharging after less than 100 s when using high voltage? Do you solve the problem? 6: The extracted beam intensity is greater than 200 μA when the arc voltage is set to 1500 V, but the discharge canÂ¿t last after 60 s, so what is the intensity of extracted beam when the system is working stably and is it sufficient to SC 200? 7: At the start of section Â¿EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS AND DISCUS-SIONÂ¿, you conclude that arc current gradually becomes stable with the increasing arc voltage, but you mention arc current is relatively stable when discharging with the further decrease of arc voltage. Please explain. 8: I suggest to replenish the lifetime test (data) of the designed ion source, for you mentioned that the motivation for this new design is to further improve the lifetime of ion source.
abstract_log.editor_notes: This work focuses on the design and analysis of the cold cathode ion source for 200 MeV superconducting isochronous cyclotron. The design is mainly based on the mechanical structure of the hot cathode source which has been chosen for SC 200. Cathode surface electric field and secondary electron simulation were performed by CST-STUDIO-SUITE program. The relationship of arc current and voltage is measured on the test bench in addition to the extracted beam intensity. There are some syntactic or formatted mistakes, and no corresponding results to the motivations (increasing lifetime of ion source). I think the final decision can depend on the revised version.
The questions have been addressed and the quality of the paper is improved. It deserves to be published as a light peer review article.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Recent Beam Commissioning of LEAF at IMP
paper.abstract: LEAF (Low Energy intense-highly-charged ion Accelerator Facility) has been successfully commissioned with several beams in CW regime, covering the M/Q from 2 to 7, such as H2+, He2+, C4+, O4+, He+, Kr13+, N2+ et al. This paper presents recent beam commissioning results.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Conceptual Design of a High-Performance Injector Based on Rf-Gated Gridded Thermionic Gun for Thz Fel
paper.abstract: Free-Electron Laser (FEL) has higher requirements on electron beam properties, for example, low transverse emittance, small energy spread, short bunch length and high peak current. Taking compactness and economy into account, we aim to design a high-performance linear accelerator based on a RF-gated gridded thermionic electron gun, which will be used as the injector of the oscillator-type THz FEL facility at Huazhong University of Science and Technology of China. The RF-gated grid will be modulated with the fundamental and 3rd harmonic microwave of the LINAC frequency, which will be very helpful to get high electron capture efficiency and short bunch length. Concerning velocity bunching effect in the LINAC, electron bunch with good symmetry of current profile and bunch length less than 10 ps can be obtained at the exit of the injector. In this paper, design and beam dynamics simulation for the high-performance injector are presented.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Design of a 217 MHz VHF Gun at Tsinghua University
paper.abstract: A 217 MHz VHF gun operating in CW mode is designing at Tsinghua University. The cathode gradient is designed to be 30 MV/m to accelerate the electron bunches up to 878 keV. The cavity profile is optimized in CST to minimize the input power, peak surface electric field, and peak wall power density. The multipacting analysis and the thermal analysis are also presented in this paper. Further gun shape optimization and mechanical design are ongoing.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: 1st+2nd Harmonic Photocathode Bimodal Gun R&D
paper.abstract: A novel Bimodal Electron Gun is designed to apply microwaves at two harmonically-related frequency in a 0.6 cell RF gun to increase the RF breakdown threshold and enhance the beam quality. This stratagem is intended to allow the RF gun structure to support a high accelera-tion gradient as well as to manipulate the emittance evolution in the half cell. By selecting a proper ampli-tude ratio and phase relationship between the first and second harmonic RF field components in the gun cavity, the superposition of the harmonic field components can provide a flat-top like RF profile to omitting the RF emittance component in the gun, while increase the RF breakdown threshold. The recent status of the Bimodal Electron Gun R&D is presented, including the designs of the novel two frequency RF structure and the simulation of the beam dynamic.
paper.agency: U.S. Dept. of Energy

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable, Poster Police Failed
paper.title: Initial Beam Commissioning of LEAF
paper.abstract: A Low Energy intense-highly-charged ion Accelerator Facility (LEAF), which mainly includes an ECR ion source, LEBT, MEBT, series of terminals and an 81.25 MHz RFQ, was designed to produce and accelerate heavy ions, from helium to uranium with A/Q between 2 and 7, to the energy of 0.5 MeV/u. The normalization root-mean-square emittance of particles at the end of LEBT is less than 0.06πmmÂ·mrad. The typical beam intensity is designed up to 2 emA CW for the uranium beam. The facility has been successfully commissioned with He+ (A/Q=4) and N2+ (A/Q=7) beams and accelerated the beams in the CW regime to the designed energy of 0.5 MeV/u. Beam properties and transmission efficiency were measured, indicating a good consistency with simulated data. Recently, a third-harmonic-buncher being used at the beginning of RFQ cavity and it increases the acceleration of RFQ to 89%. Another project of accelerated beams called 'cocktail beam' was proposed, it's a mixed beam extracted by ECR ion source, and format at beam line. Cocktails can be mixed by different beams from the similar charge-to-mass ratio to any r/q beams, and it can be accelerate simultaneously and divided by energy dispersive detector.

paper.main_class: MC3: Novel Particle Sources and Acceleration Techniques
paper.title: Characterisation Study of Fast Neutron Sources Based on Proton Accelerators at KOMAC
paper.abstract: In this paper, we introduce two neutron sources based on proton accelerators; a quasi mono-energetic neutron source driven by a 1.7MV tandem accelerator and a pulsed white neutron source based on a 100 MeV linear proton accelerator, which are installed at Korea Multi-purpose Accelerator Complex (KOMAC) of Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute (KAERI). The white pulsed neutrons are generated by bombarding a pure copper target with a pulsed proton beam. It was mainly characterised by Monte Carlo simulations, which were validated with experimental measurements. Because the proton driver beam has high peak current, direct measurement of the fast neuton is extremely challenging. We have constructed a fast neutron detection system based on scintillation detection devices and measured the flux and energy of the pulsed neutrons. The kinetic energy of the pulsed neutrons extends up to 100 MeV with source intensity of 10^13 neutrons per second at the proton beam power of 1 uA. On the other hand, the quasi mono-energetic neutrons are generated by the nuclear reaction of incident protons in a lithium target. The kinetic energy of the neutrons could be uniquely defined with input parameters, such as incident proton energy, scattering angle, and target thickness. The theoretical calculations were then validated with experimental measurements. Fast neutron flux is monitored with a He-3 detector embedded in a specialized moderator. Also the energy measurement of the mono-energetic neutrons was done with CLYC detectors and pulse shape discrimination techniques. The mono-energetic neutron-source intensity was found to be 10^6 neutrons per second at the proton beam current of 1 uA.
paper.agency: This work has been supported through KOMAC operation fund of KAERI and the NRF of Korea Grant funded by the Korea government (MSIT) (No. NRF-2018M2A2A6A02071070 and NRF-2018M2A2B3A02072238).

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Characterization of Short Pulse Extraction from EBIS's and Status on 7 T EBIS at KOMAC
paper.abstract: Electron Beam Ion Sources (EBIS's) are being developed and characterized at Korea Multipurpose Accelerator Complex (KOMAC). There are two commercially available EBIS's, viz EBIS-A and EBIS-SC, and a 7 Tesla EBIS which is currently being manufactured. From the EBIS-A and EBIS-SC, we extract short proton pulses by varying the extraction time. We characterize and compare ion charge and pulse width measured from the EBIS-A and EBIS-SC while varying the extraction time from 50 ns to 10 μs. It will be used as a short proton source of the 100 MeV proton linac for obtaining short neutron pulses. For the 7 T EBIS, we have finished the electron beam simulation, construction of 7T superconducting solenoid, the electron gun and design of the drift tubes. We show the current status of manufacturing the 7 T EBIS and further construction plans for the 7 T EBIS. Once completed, this will be coupled with a Radio-Frequency Quadrupole for an ion irradiation facility. In this paper, we report the entire EBIS development for various beam application purpose at KOMAC.
paper.agency: This work has been supported through KOMAC operation fund of KAERI by MSIT and the NRF of Korea grant funded by the Korea government (MSIT) (No. NRF-2017M2A2A6A02071070).

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Improvement of the Microwave Ion Source at KOMAC
paper.abstract: A microwave ion source has been used as an injector for a 100-MeV proton linac at Korea Multi-purpose Accelerator Complex (KOMAC). It is a compact one which uses one solenoid coil. The microwave source and magnet power supply are located in the ground potential by using a DC break and magnet insulator. A BN lining is used to increase the proton fraction. Recently, the geometry of the solenoid magnet was changed to improve the insulation of the magnet. And the lining material was also changed. In this paper, the modifications of the microwave ion source are introduced and the test results are discussed.
paper.agency: This work has been supported through KOMAC operation fund of KAERI by MSIT and the NRF of Korea grant funded by the Korea government (MSIT)

paper.abstract: Physical design of the compact superconducting cyclotron SC230 (91.5MHz) has been performed. The cyclotron will deliver up to 230 MeV beam for proton therapy and medico-biological research. We have performed simulations of magnetic and accelerating systems of the SC230 cyclotron and specified the main parameters of the accelerator.

paper.title: Beam Dynamics Simulations in the Dubna SC230 Superconducting Cyclotron for Proton Therapy
paper.abstract: We present results of the beam dynamics simulation for the compact isochronous superconducting cyclotron SC230. We have performed beam tracking starting from the ion source. The extraction system scheme and results of beam extraction simulations are presented. The codes and methods used for beam tracking are briefly described.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: The Pre-Injector and Photocathode Gun Design for the MAX IV SXL
paper.abstract: The design of the pre-injector, including the new gun, for the SXL project is being finalised for the desired modes of operation, 100 pC and 10 pC with short bunches. The photocathode gun is currently being manufactured and experiments in the MAX IV guntest facility are under preparation to verify the design. In this paper we present the design of the gun and the pre-injector and show some results from simulations using MOGA indicating an emittance below 0.3 mm mrad.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable
paper.title: Child-Langmuir Law for Photoinjectors
paper.abstract: The space-charge field at the cathode limits the current density extracted from particle sources such as photoinjectors. For a long time, the maximum current has been estimated by using the classical Child-Langmuir law, which is derived with an assumption inconsistent with the conditions of modern laser-driven electron guns. Here, we introduce a theoretical model that accurately accounts for space-charge effects in transversely confined particle beams emerging from photocathodes. The model enables us to (i) determine the maximum current density extractable from the photocathode for an arbitrary cathode radius, (ii) reveal its dependence on the transverse profile of the particle beam and (iii) predict its upper limit for structured beams such as the ones produced by surface-plasmon resonance-enhanced photocathodes.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.publishable: No, Editor Status Code is not Publishable, Final QA Not Publishable
paper.title: High Repetition Rate Thermionic Electron Source for Accelerator-Based Light Sources
paper.abstract: At the TU/e a thermionic electron injector will be built capable of supplying electron bunches at GHz repetition rates. With a high current density, hexaboride compounds such as CeB6 and LaB6 can provide sufficient charge for the use in x-ray generation while their low work function allows for a lower operating temperature and higher brightness. Simulations show that through a custom design 100kV DC source a high quality, high current continuous electron beam can be generated and subsequently chopped into a pulsed beam. The latter is done by an RF cavity operating in both the fundamental mode and a higher harmonic mode to achieve a duty cycle of 30% with minimal loss of beam quality. Finally, RF compression, also using a higher harmonic mode, prepares the pulsed beam for injection into an X-band linear accelerator for use in an X-ray light source. With the high repetition rate the average current is vastly improved in comparison to photoemission based sources, increasing the output of an X-ray source.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: RF Conditioning of the CLARA 400 Hz Photoinjector
paper.abstract: Automated conditioning of the 400 Hz photoinjector for CLARA was begun and the conditioning program refined. The conditioning was performed at 100 Hz. Masks were used to detect breakdowns in the reflected power and phase, and the breakdown rate was limited to 5x106 breakdowns per pulse. The cavity gradient and breakdown rate evolution over the conditioning time is presented. Post-pulse multipactor and other evidence of electron effects were detected. Possible mechanisms for this are discussed. The conditioning was interrupted by breakdown in the waveguide after reaching 2.5 MW, and will be resumed after the planned 6 month shutdown of CLARA.

paper.main_class: MC2: Photon Sources and Electron Accelerators
paper.title: Re-optimisation of the ALICE Gun Upgrade Design for the 500-pC Bunch Charge Requirements of PERLE
paper.abstract: The injector for PERLE, a planned ERL test facility, must be capable of delivering 500 pC bunches at a repetition rate of 40.1 MHz to provide a beam with 20 mA average current with a projected rms emittance of less than 6 mm mrad. This must be achieved at two different operational voltages 350 kV and 220 kV for unpolarised and polarised operation respectively. The PERLE injector will be based on an upgrade of a DC photocathode electron gun operated previously at ALICE ERL at Daresbury. The upgrade will add a load lock system for photocathode interchange. This paper presents the results of a re-optimisation of the electrode system as ALICE operated with a bunch charge of around 80 pC while PERLE needs a bunch charge of 500 pC. This re-optimisation was done using the many-objective genetic algorithm NSGAIII to minimise both the slice emittance and transverse beam size for both required operational voltages.

paper.main_class: MC4: Hadron Accelerators
paper.title: Progress on Design Studies for the ISIS II Upgrade
paper.abstract: ISIS, the spallation neutron source at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory in the UK, uses a 50 Hz, 800 MeV proton RCS to provide a beam power of 0.2 MW, delivered in 0.4 us long pulses. Detailed studies are now under way for a major upgrade. Accelerator designs using FFAs, conventional accumulator and synchrotron rings are being considered for the required MW beam power. This paper summarises the scope of the different research incorporating results from recent target studies and user consultations. Preliminary results for Fixed Field Alternating gradient (FFA) rings and conventional rings located in the existing ISIS synchrotron hall are presented.
